awd_titl_txt: EAGER:REAL-D: Smart Decision Making using Data and Advanced Modeling Approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed exploratory research project aims to develop a next-generation autonomous manufacturing process for pharmaceutical production that integrates product and process informatics with knowledge management. The integration of process data, process models, and information management tools will enable adaptive adjustment to the operating conditions to compensate for variability in raw materials and changing product needs. The research team will take advantage of the facilities of the Center for Structured Organic Particulate Systems (C-SOPS) at Rutgers University for proof of principle studies and generation of experimental data for advancing fundamental understanding of each process.

To enable the transition towards more autonomous and de-centralized decisions across the entire manufacturing supply chain, it is imperative to develop an integrated platform to: (a) acquire data regarding process and product operations from the manufacturing facility using data historian platforms; (b) utilize the data to extract further knowledge on process understanding; and (c) use this knowledge to dynamically and adaptively improve process operations. For task (a), the use of a data management system, such as OSI PI, is proposed with the ability to receive data from multiple sources including the control platform as well as the Process Analytical Technology (PAT) data management tool. This platform has the capability to build up recipe hierarchical structure using Event Frame functionality and periodically push the data into a cloud system for permanent enterprise-wide data storage and efficient sharing. For task (b), the use of advanced statistical and machine learning methods is proposed, in combination with data reconciliation methods.  Finally, for task (c), information acquired will be utilized to adapt the model feasible space by building accurate surrogate models and adaptively refine them using the online data acquisition. Although the focus will be on pharmaceutical production processes, the proposed work, if successful, can have significant broader impacts on a variety of industrial processes. Two PhD students will be trained on the development of a cutting-edge framework for autonomous manufacturing processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of this project is to develop a cyber-physical representation of a pharmaceutical tablet manufacturing process that combines models, data, hardware, and software components for smart decision making. The expected longer-term outcome is for the manufacturing process to self-learn and improve to be able to locate optimal design spaces for performance improvement, independently from human intervention.

    The project outcomes are several. Firstly, we were able to demonstrate the complete physical integration of a pharmaceutical tablet manufacturing process consisting of key unit operations such as granulation, drying and milling with a control hardware, data historian and a cloud platform. The cloud platform was also integrated with simulation models of the granulation, drying, and milling unit operations. Off-line analytical data were measured from laboratory equipment and sent to an electronic laboratory notebook (ELN) which were then stored in the cloud platform for interfacing with the simulation models. Similarly, in-line data such as particle size analysis and near infrared spectroscopy were measured and sent to the control platform and data historian for in-process controls, followed by storage in the cloud platform for use in the simulation models. Off-line and in-line data were used for simulation model training and update which then provided new optimal operating conditions for the physical process. Secondly, we developed hybrid simulation models for pharmaceutical unit operations such as granulation, drying and milling. These models combined the accuracy of first principles-based models but also the computational efficiency of reduced order models such as neural-network based machine learning models. We were able to demonstrate that the simulation models matched key experimental trends and sensitivities but could also be simulated very efficiently for their use in effective process control and optimization.

    The above project outcomes not only advanced the scientific development of pharmaceutical tablet manufacturing but are also in line with the U.S Food and Drug Administration’s mandate to improve science-based understanding of pharmaceutical manufacturing. Finally, all developed work products were tech-transferrable to other process industries that require smart decision-making for their industrial manufacturing processes.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2024
Modified by: Rohit Ramachandran
